quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The question is, how would you feel if you could no longer use this product? Once you got a high enough percentage of users saying they'd be very disappointed, most of those products did pretty well. If you felt too low, those products tended to suffer.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A practical PMF diagnostic: measure “very disappointed” users and use the percentage as a leading indicator of product strength.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Just ignore the people who say they'd be somewhat disappointed. They're telling you it's a nice to have. If you start paying attention to what your somewhat disappointed users are telling you and then you start tweaking onboarding and product based on their feedback, maybe you're going to dilute it for your must have users.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance on feedback prioritization: focusing on lukewarm users can weaken the product for the core “must-have” segment.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It's usually much more function of onboarding to the right user experience than it is about the kind of the tactical things that people try to do to improve retention.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Reframes retention work as primarily an onboarding-to-value problem rather than a set of surface-level retention tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It's a simple question that helps you figure out, does anyone consider your product a must-have, or ideally, who and how many people consider it, but ultimately it's about trying to figure out is your product a must-have, which could be equated to having product market fit.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Defines the underlying methodology: PMF as “must-have” status, and the goal of identifying both the segment and its size.

quotes.topic_title: Defining the Sean Ellis PMF test
quotes.text: It's a simple question that helps you figure out, does anyone consider your product a must-have, or ideally, who and how many people consider it, but ultimately it's about trying to figure out is your product a must-have, which could be equated to having product market fit.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Defines the PMF test as a practical way to measure whether the product is a true must-have (a proxy for product-market fit).

quotes.topic_title: Defining the Sean Ellis PMF test
quotes.text: And so the question is, how would you feel if you could no longer use this product?
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Gives the core survey question practitioners can deploy immediately to assess must-have demand.

quotes.topic_title: Defining the Sean Ellis PMF test
quotes.text: And I give them the choice, very disappointed, somewhat disappointed, or even not disappointed or not applicable, I've already stopped using the product.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Provides the exact response options that operationalize the survey into actionable segments.

quotes.topic_title: Defining the Sean Ellis PMF test
quotes.text: And what I'm trying to find are those people who say, "I would be very disappointed if I could no longer use this product," then that's a really powerful vein to dig into when you discover that you actually have some people who would give a crap if your product disappears.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Explains how to interpret results: focus on “very disappointed” users as the highest-signal group for understanding and scaling PMF.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Gamma has become one of the fastest growing AI web products in the world, adding 20 million new users just this past year and is setting its sights on becoming the modern alternative to PowerPoint.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete growth data point and positioning statement that can inform how practitioners benchmark traction and craft category-replacement narratives.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And these pop-ups are becoming less and less effective since most users don't read what they say. They just want to close them as soon as possible.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that common onboarding patterns can backfire, pushing teams to rethink in-product education tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And they do pop-ups too, but their nudges are based on in-product like confusion or intent classification, which makes them much less annoying and much more impactful.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical methodology: trigger guidance based on detected intent/confusion rather than generic blasts to improve UX and effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I would say it's a leading indicator of product market fit. The lightning indicator is, do they actually keep using it?
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A memorable mental model separating survey-based PMF signals from the more definitive behavioral metric of retention.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So probably retention cohorts are more accurate, but the problem is, like your time at Airbnb, how long do you have to look at a retention cohort before you know that you've actually long-term retained someone?
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Highlights a real-world measurement tradeoff: retention is best, but teams must decide the time horizon needed to confidently call “long-term” retention.

quotes.topic_title: 40% threshold and leading indicator logic
quotes.text: I would say it's a leading indicator of product market fit. The lightning indicator is, do they actually keep using it? So probably retention cohorts are more accurate, but the problem is, like your time at Airbnb, how long do you have to look at a retention cohort before you know that you've actually long-term retained someone?
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Defines a practical mental model: the 40% survey is a fast leading indicator, while retention cohorts are the slower but truer proof of product-market fit.

quotes.topic_title: 40% threshold and leading indicator logic
quotes.text: And so with this question, you can kind of find out day one, you don't need a good analytics system in place to be able to see if product market fit exists.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for early teams: use the survey to assess PMF directionally even before robust analytics exist.

quotes.topic_title: 40% threshold and leading indicator logic
quotes.text: And so over time, I started to see there was a pattern that once you got a high enough percentage of users saying they'd be very disappointed, most of those very disappointed without the product, most of those products did pretty well. And then if you felt too low, those products tended to suffer.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Explains the empirical basis for the benchmark—pattern recognition across many startups linking “very disappointed” share to outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: 40% threshold and leading indicator logic
quotes.text: So I actually had a company where I had committed to work with them. It was right after I left Dropbox and I committed to work with these guys for six months to help them grow. I ran the question and it came back at only 7% of users saying they'd be very disappointed without the product. And so I'm like, "I have six months to help them grow and they're only at 7% right now. It might take six months to get the 40%. Am I doing them a disservice by being in a growth role and being on payroll during this period of time?" But fortunately with the signal and the information we got from the initial survey, we were able to get them at 40% in two weeks.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Concrete case study showing how the survey can reveal low PMF early and guide rapid iteration to reach the 40% threshold quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: Lookout from 7% to 40%
quotes.text: So the company called Lookout, it's a mobile security company, and now most of the things in Lookout are built into iPhones and Androids. But at that time, the product had everything from backup my data to find my lost phone to protecting your phone with a firewall and antivirus. And so when we ran this initial survey, I dug into the 7% who said they'd be very disappointed without the product and found that most of that 7% were focused on the antivirus functionality.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Shows a practical PMF diagnostic method: analyze the “very disappointed” segment to identify the true core value driving retention.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: Lookout from 7% to 40%
quotes.text: And so now we knew, okay, it's antivirus that people really valued. And so step one was just reposition the product on antivirus. So that kind of creates a filter. So anyone who now is coming in to sign up for the product who doesn't care about antivirus is not going to convert, and those who are excited about antivirus are going to convert.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A positioning strategy that intentionally narrows the funnel to attract higher-intent users aligned with the product’s strongest value.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: Lookout from 7% to 40%
quotes.text: But then the second thing that we did was we streamlined onboarding so that the first thing that they did after signing up for the product was to set up the antivirus and then get a message "you're now protected from viruses."
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Illustrates “speed to value” in onboarding by making the primary value moment happen immediately after signup.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: Lookout from 7% to 40%
quotes.text: And so it's really the combination of those two things. It's set the right expectations and then speed to value. And so the next cohort of people that we surveyed were at 40% saying they'd be very disappointed without the product. So that literally took two weeks to make those changes. Six months later, it was 60% on the score.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Provides a repeatable growth/PMF playbook plus concrete before/after metrics and timeline impact.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: Lookout from 7% to 40%
quotes.text: I think that having that kind of finger on the pulse early in the business was important to build the muscle in the business to be really responsive as the market changed.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Highlights the organizational advantage of continuous customer/market feedback loops to adapt as conditions shift.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding as the main lever for retention
quotes.text: So the first is just follow this thread of basically you're sharing kind of a growth strategy that I imagine you execute, is look for the percentage of people that would be very disappointed if your product went away, see who they are, see what they're excited about and lean into that both positioning-wise, onboarding-wise, and probably also cut out stuff from your product that they don't care about.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete growth/PMF workflow: measure “very disappointed,” identify the core users/value, then focus positioning and onboarding around it (and remove distractions).

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding as the main lever for retention
quotes.text: So it made more sense to say, "Let's just sequence the onboarding so that we're highlighting this and onboarding to this." That was a little easier to sell.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Practical tactic for teams with limited product-change leverage: improve retention by re-sequencing onboarding to spotlight the core value.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding as the main lever for retention
quotes.text: Right. And then that ultimately moving retention is really hard, but it's usually much more function of onboarding to the right user experience than it is about the tactical things that people try to do to improve retention.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Counterintuitive retention lever: onboarding-to-the-right-experience often matters more than common “tactical” retention tricks.

quotes.topic_title: What 40% really means: deepen user understanding
quotes.text: Yeah, I mean it tells you something really important, which is, you haven't created something that people don't care about. So that's an important insight. But until you deeply understand that product market fit, you kind of don't have the tools to be able to grow the business.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Reframes the 40% result as a starting signal—not permission to scale—until you understand the underlying drivers of must-have demand.

quotes.topic_title: What 40% really means: deepen user understanding
quotes.text: So that's really the next step, is to dig in and figure out who considers it a must have, how are they using the product, what did they use before, what problem are they solving.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A practical checklist for turning a PMF survey score into concrete user understanding and growth inputs.

quotes.topic_title: What 40% really means: deepen user understanding
quotes.text: One of my favorite questions is, "What is the primary benefit that you get?"
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A simple follow-up question that helps isolate the core value prop among “very disappointed” users.

quotes.topic_title: What 40% really means: deepen user understanding
quotes.text: And then the question that follows on that next survey is, "Why is that benefit important to you?" And then I start to get really good context.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology: move from benefit selection to the deeper “why” that unlocks messaging and targeting.

quotes.topic_title: What 40% really means: deepen user understanding
quotes.text: And so when I then was trying to figure out how to acquire customers, when I tested "drowning in email?", that set such a good hook.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Concrete example of translating qualitative “why” context into a high-performing acquisition message.

quotes.topic_title: How strict is 40% and why it helps teams
quotes.text: I don't think it's that firm.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Reframes the 40% metric as a guideline rather than a rigid cutoff, reducing over-optimization around the exact number.

quotes.topic_title: How strict is 40% and why it helps teams
quotes.text: To me, I think the real power is having some kind of target for the team to be shooting for that basically says, "We're not going to aggressively start to grow until we hit this target."
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Provides an actionable operating rule: set a shared PMF target and explicitly delay aggressive growth until it’s met.

quotes.topic_title: How strict is 40% and why it helps teams
quotes.text: And I think that as just a focusing piece is really important because I think one of the biggest challenges in an early stage startup is half the people feel like we're years from having this product ready to grow, and half the people are like, "What are we waiting for?"
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Highlights a common organizational misalignment that a concrete PMF definition can resolve.

quotes.topic_title: How strict is 40% and why it helps teams
quotes.text: Where if you can actually get people on the same page of what does product market fit look like for our business, and it's at that point that we're going to.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Emphasizes aligning the org around a specific, shared definition of PMF as a prerequisite for scaling decisions.

quotes.topic_title: How strict is 40% and why it helps teams
quotes.text: "When do we step on the gas? What is the combination of factors that need to be in place before we start pouring fuel on the early fire?"
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for scaling: identify the conditions that justify accelerating growth rather than scaling by default.

quotes.topic_title: False positives: switching costs and investment effects
quotes.text: What I can tell you is that not necessarily a false positive, but what is driving people to say they'd be very disappointed.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Reframes “false positives” as a prompt to investigate underlying drivers rather than dismissing the score.

quotes.topic_title: False positives: switching costs and investment effects
quotes.text: One of my favorite books is Hooked by Nir Eyal and he talks about in the kind of engagement loop that your last step is investment.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Introduces the “investment” step as a mental model for why users may report high disappointment.

quotes.topic_title: False positives: switching costs and investment effects
quotes.text: I ran the survey thinking, "Yeah, you've had products like Wix and Weebly that have come on to the market since this more legacy website building product has been around. I personally think they're a little easier to use, they're a little better." And so I didn't have high hopes when I ran the survey, but it came back with one of the highest scores I'd ever seen. And it was like 90% of the people saying they'd be very disappointed if they could no longer use the product.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Concrete example showing a “commoditized” product can score extremely high due to factors beyond superior UX.

quotes.topic_title: False positives: switching costs and investment effects
quotes.text: And then when I want to dug into it again, it comes back to that Nir Eyal Hooked model, is that the investment people have made in building that website, they put so much into that they know exactly how to make the changes and the kind of the CMS kind of side of things, they have spent a lot of time just making it beautiful.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Explains how user investment/time spent creates perceived value and reluctance to switch—boosting “very disappointed” scores.

quotes.topic_title: False positives: switching costs and investment effects
quotes.text: So sort of switching costs I think can factor in there. So it's a function of both switching costs and utility of the product.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Actionable interpretation: treat survey results as a blend of switching costs and true product utility when diagnosing PMF.

quotes.topic_title: When to run the survey and key limitations
quotes.text: What I recommend is a random sample of people who've really used your product. So they've gone in, they didn't just sign up, but they went in and hopefully hit that deviation moment. They've used it twice, two plus times, and they've ideally used it, say, within the last week or two weeks, so they haven't churned yet. So if it's a random sample of those people, that's kind of the ideal time to ask it.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Clear methodology for when and who to survey so results reflect meaningful product usage rather than superficial exposure.

quotes.topic_title: When to run the survey and key limitations
quotes.text: But it's okay if you're hitting people who've used it months later, but in that Lookout example that I gave, if I'm testing people's perception of the product after I made updates to the onboarding, I'm going to only want to survey people who went through the new onboarding.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Practical guidance on aligning survey sampling with the specific product experience you’re trying to evaluate (e.g., new onboarding).

quotes.topic_title: When to run the survey and key limitations
quotes.text: Yeah. I think one-off products would probably, like, how would you feel if you could no longer watch the movie you just watch? I wouldn't care. Even when I run a workshop, I don't run this as part of my survey after I do a workshop because how would you feel if you could no longer attend the workshop you just attended? It doesn't make sense.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Defines a key limitation: the survey breaks down for one-off experiences where “can’t use anymore” is inherently irrelevant.

quotes.topic_title: When to run the survey and key limitations
quotes.text: Once all of those things are working well, then I'll obsess on the customer acquisition side. But customer acquisition is so hard that if you're not really efficient at converting and retaining and monetizing people, you're going to really struggle on the customer acquisition side.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A sequencing framework for growth: validate must-have and optimize conversion/retention/monetization before scaling acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Cultural thresholds and origin story of the question
quotes.text: But I do think he brought up a really good point that, culturally, some people are going to be more optimistic or pessimistic.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Highlights that product-market-fit thresholds (like 40%) may need calibration based on cultural response bias.

quotes.topic_title: Cultural thresholds and origin story of the question
quotes.text: Well, if I flip it and say, "How would you feel if you could no longer use this product?" I'll probably get a more honest answer back from them.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A practical survey methodology: reframing from satisfaction to loss aversion to elicit more truthful signal, especially from hard-to-please stakeholders.

quotes.topic_title: Cultural thresholds and origin story of the question
quotes.text: But initially, it was more about thinking just senior management to get a more honest answer out of them.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Explains the origin of the “disappointed if you couldn’t use it” question as a tool to overcome systematically lukewarm satisfaction ratings.

quotes.topic_title: Cultural thresholds and origin story of the question
quotes.text: And over the six months, it flipped from 90% being people who try things that they want to try cool new technology to six months later, it was people who only are going to try something that they feel like is useful.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Concrete Dropbox example showing how user motivation shifts from novelty-driven early adopters to utility-driven mainstream users as a product matures.

quotes.topic_title: Cultural thresholds and origin story of the question
quotes.text: But what's cool is just because what motivates you to try something is you're an early adopter and you want to try something cool, if you're going to keep using it, it's because it's giving you some utility.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Counterintuitive retention insight: acquisition can be driven by “cool,” but sustained usage depends on real utility—use early adopters to locate that value.

quotes.topic_title: Durability, sample size, and market size tradeoffs
quotes.text: Yeah, I haven't seen it really fade back down, but I've seen companies fail despite having it. And I think a lot of times then, it becomes an execution challenge.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Highlights that hitting the 40% “very disappointed” threshold doesn’t guarantee success—execution becomes the main risk after PMF.

quotes.topic_title: Durability, sample size, and market size tradeoffs
quotes.text: It's really funny. So much of the stuff I self-learned, but I basically at one point said I need at least 30 responses, and I just thought I randomly made up a number and then I had people telling me, "Yeah, 30 is the minimum that you want on stuff."
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Gives a practical minimum sample-size heuristic practitioners can use to trust PMF survey results.

quotes.topic_title: Durability, sample size, and market size tradeoffs
quotes.text: But then I try to force people in a bucket, and then I can run filters on each of those buckets and I'll be like, "Oh, people who use it this way are like 60% likely to be very disappointed without the product, but people who use it this way are 35% likely to be very disappointed, but way more people use it the 35% way."
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Introduces a segmentation methodology: bucket users by use case and compare PMF strength vs market size across segments.

quotes.topic_title: Durability, sample size, and market size tradeoffs
quotes.text: I prefer a more passionate customer base and work from there, just because I think your biggest competition when you're really innovating is just being irrelevant. And so if you're deeply relevant to anyone, I think that gives you a much better chance of long-term success.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A clear strategic heuristic: prioritize a passionate niche first to avoid irrelevance, then expand.

quotes.topic_title: Tools, retention cohorts, and operationalizing PMF surveys
quotes.text: retention cohorts don't give you any of the qualitative insights into the why, so that's why we continue to do the survey.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A clear methodology: pair quantitative retention cohorts with qualitative PMF surveys to understand both what happens and why.

quotes.topic_title: Tools, retention cohorts, and operationalizing PMF surveys
quotes.text: if you're churning out all the customers who were saying that they'd be very disappointed without the product, then okay, let's retrench and rethink, do we really have product-market fit here and what do we need to do to get it if we don't?
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic: if your “must-have” users churn, treat it as a PMF red flag and pause growth to fix fundamentals.

quotes.topic_title: Tools, retention cohorts, and operationalizing PMF surveys
quotes.text: So if you think about it, how would you feel if you can no longer use this feature starts to give you, again, the signal, is that feature a must-have feature? And if it's not, maybe we shouldn't have it.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A feature-level PMF test that helps teams decide what to keep, improve, or remove based on “must-have” value.

quotes.topic_title: Tools, retention cohorts, and operationalizing PMF surveys
quotes.text: So one of the things I've always said is just ignore the people who say they'd be somewhat disappointed. They're telling you it's a nice to have. They're as good as gone, so just ignore those guys.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prioritization rule: don’t optimize for “nice-to-have” users because it can distract from serving must-have users.

quotes.topic_title: Tools, retention cohorts, and operationalizing PMF surveys
quotes.text: Okay, what is the benefit that my must-have users are focused on? And then of the users who say they'd be somewhat disappointed, so the nice-to-have users, of those users who are also focused on that benefit, what do they need in the product for it then to become a must-have for them?
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A targeted upgrade framework: convert “somewhat disappointed” users by aligning improvements to the core benefit valued by must-have users.

quotes.topic_title: PMF survey templates and benefit/alternatives questions
quotes.text: Eventually the survey.io got closed down, but essentially the template that I typically used was then moved to PMFsurvey.com.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Points practitioners to a concrete, ready-to-use source for the PMF survey template and related questions.

quotes.topic_title: PMF survey templates and benefit/alternatives questions
quotes.text: And so you'll see some other questions that I have on there as well, like what would you use instead if this product were no longer available?
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Adds a practical “alternatives” question that helps diagnose uniqueness and switching behavior, not just satisfaction.

quotes.topic_title: PMF survey templates and benefit/alternatives questions
quotes.text: And that's one of the interesting things is you start to see people who say they'd be somewhat disappointed, usually, they're focused on a commodity use case and they know an easy alternative to switch to.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Offers a diagnostic pattern: “somewhat disappointed” often signals commodity value and low switching costs.

quotes.topic_title: PMF survey templates and benefit/alternatives questions
quotes.text: So to be a must-have, it needs to be both valuable and unique.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for interpreting PMF results: value alone isn’t enough without differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: PMF survey templates and benefit/alternatives questions
quotes.text: Just one quick interjection there is that when I coined growth hacking, I did not think of it as a bunch of one-off hacks. What I thought of it was what's more about what is the way to ultimately drive sustainable growth?
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Reframes “growth hacking” as a sustainable-growth discipline rather than short-lived tactics, challenging the common interpretation.

quotes.topic_title: Reframing growth hacking as sustainable growth
quotes.text: Yeah. Just one quick interjection there is that when I coined growth hacking, I did not think of it as a bunch of one-off hacks. What I thought of it was what's more about what is the way to ultimately drive sustainable growth?
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Reframes “growth hacking” away from gimmicks toward a long-term, sustainable growth mindset.

quotes.topic_title: Reframing growth hacking as sustainable growth
quotes.text: Yeah, I just said it's about looking at every single thing that you're doing and scrutinizing its impact on growth in the business.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Defines a practical methodology: evaluate all work through the lens of measurable growth impact.

quotes.topic_title: Reframing growth hacking as sustainable growth
quotes.text: And startups just don't have the luxury to do all of those things, and so you got to really focus on how do I acquire customers to an experience that's going to make them keep using this product?
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization for startups: acquisition must connect directly to retention-driving product experience.

quotes.topic_title: Reframing growth hacking as sustainable growth
quotes.text: but I think it at least opened the conversation to getting more people thinking about maybe we should be thinking about growth in a different way than as it's traditionally taught in marketing courses in school.
quotes.speaker: Sean Ellis
quotes.context: Challenges traditional awareness-first marketing playbooks and argues for a different growth approach for startups.
